My Favorite Readings in 2013

[1]
C. U. Andersen and S. Pold, ‘Competing compatibilities – Is the “interface” an alienating ideal for Human/Computer activity?’, World of the News, vol. 1, no. 2 [Online]. Available: http://www.aprja.net/?p=79
[2]
S. Papert, ‘Computer Criticism vs. Technocentric Thinking’, Educational Researcher, vol. 16, no. 1, pp. 22–30, 1987.
[3]
M. L. Minsky, ‘Music, mind, and meaning’, Massachusetts Institute of Technology (Cambridge, MA US), AI-M-616, 1981 [Online]. Available: http://opac.inria.fr/record=b1008812
[4]
M.-Z. Poh, D. J. McDuff, and R. W. Picard, ‘Non-contact, automated cardiac pulse measurements using video imaging and blind source separation’, Opt. Express, vol. 18, no. 10, pp. 10762–10774, May 2010. DOI:10.1364/oe.18.010762
[5]
A. M. Turing, ‘On Computable Numbers, with an application to the Entscheidungsproblem’, Proceedings of the London Mathematical Society, vol. 42, pp. 230–265, 1936.
[6]
E. Dijkstra, On the cruelty of really teaching computing science. [Online]. Available: http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/EWD/ewd10xx/EWD1036.PDF
[7]
M. Resnick, ‘Reviving Papert’s Dream’, Educational Technology, vol. 52, no. 4, Aug. 2012.
[8]
M. Resnick, J. Maloney, A. Monroy-Hernández, N. Rusk, E. Eastmond, K. Brennan, A. Millner, E. Rosenbaum, J. Silver, B. Silverman, and Y. Kafai, ‘Scratch: Programming for All’, Commun. ACM, vol. 52, no. 11, pp. 60–67, Nov. 2009. DOI:10.1145/1592761.1592779
[9]
F. Nake, ‘Semiotic Animal | Semiotic Machine: Machinizing the Work of Our Heads—A Feast for the Inhuman Human’, Design of the In/Human. [Online]. Available: http://www.design-in-human.de/lectures/nake.html
[10]
H. Ishii, ‘Tangible Bits: Beyond Pixels’, in Proceedings of the 2Nd International Conference on Tangible and Embedded Interaction, New York, NY, USA, 2008, pp. xv–xxv [Online]. Available: http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/1347390.1347392
[11]
A. C. Kay, ‘The early history of Smalltalk’, SIGPLAN Not., vol. 28, no. 3, pp. 69–95, Mar. 1993. DOI:10.1145/155360.155364
[12]
D. M. Ritchie and K. Thompson, ‘The UNIX Time-Sharing System’, Communications of the ACM, vol. 17, pp. 365–375, 1974.
[13]
F. Nake, ‘Work, Design, Computers, Artifacts’, in (Re)Searching The Digital Bauhaus, Springer London, 2009, pp. 309–331 [Online]. Available: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/978-1-84800-350-7_17

Some of the papers I enjoyed reading the most.
Most papers deal with computer sciences or aesthetics.

Hendrik, January 2014
